display_asset.caption: Jerry Seinfeld knocked on a window of the Oval Office as part of his series, "Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee."
display_asset.credit: Pete Souza/The White House

summaries.body: President Obama rode around in a Corvette with Jerry Seinfeld for his show “Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee.” Mr. Seinfeld asked him about his underwear.

display_asset.caption: A New Jersey man was killed when he fell from the scaffolding on the Four Seasons Hotel in Midtown.
display_asset.credit: Bryan R. Smith for The New York Times

summaries.body: A 24-year-old New Jersey man fell to his death trying to climb the Four Seasons Hotel in Manhattan with a friend to take pictures. They had reached the 51st floor.

display_asset.credit: Mark J. Terrill/Associated Press

summaries.body: Tonya Couch, the mother of the "affluenza" teenager, has arrived in the United States after being deported from Mexico, where her son remains.

display_asset.credit: Justin Tallis/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

summaries.body: George Lucas has criticized the latest installment of “Star Wars,” the series he created, in an interview with Charlie Rose, describing the film as too “retro” for his taste.

display_asset.caption: A line for police checks to enter the Red Square in Moscow on Wednesday. Red Square will be closed to the public on New Year's Eve, although the Russian authorities said the move had nothing to do with security issues.
display_asset.credit: Maxim Shipenkov/European Pressphoto Agency

summaries.body: As New Year's Eve unfolds around the world, cities have increased police presences or scaled back festivities after terrorist attacks and threats.

display_asset.credit: Mark Metcalfe/Getty Images

summaries.body: Critics seem to favor Adele's "25," but readers of Rolling Stone went a different way in selecting the best album of 2015: Adam Lambert's "The Original High."

display_asset.credit: Tony Demin for The New York Times

summaries.body: Once seen as a low-fat red-meat alternative, emu never won over the American palate, and the number being raised in the U.S. has dropped 72 percent in a decade.

display_asset.caption: The Toys “R” Us store in Times Square closed its doors on Wednesday after delighting shoppers for more than 14 years with its indoor Ferris wheel and 20-foot-tall robotic T. rex.
display_asset.credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times

summaries.body: The Toys "R" Us store in Times Square closed its doors on Wednesday after luring shoppers for more than 14 years with its indoor Ferris wheel and 20-foot-tall robotic T. rex.

display_asset.caption: Axl Rose during a concert in Bangalore, India in 2012.
display_asset.credit: Aijaz Rahi/Associated Press

summaries.body: The Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival will host at least two rock ’n’ roll reunions in 2016: Guns N’ Roses — a gigantic get — and LCD Soundsystem.

display_asset.caption: Donald J. Trump during a news conference in New York in September.
display_asset.credit: Michael Appleton for The New York Times

summaries.body: Donald J. Trump appears to be more concerned about the quality of his hair than the quality of the air: He has criticized restrictions on aerosol hairspray.

display_asset.caption: Carrie Fisher and Harrison Ford in "Star Wars: The Force Awakens."
display_asset.credit: Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures

summaries.body: Carrie Fisher, who reprised her role as Princess Leia in the new "Star Wars" movie, asked those criticizing her to "Please stop debating whether or not I aged well."

display_asset.caption: Chinese rescue workers righting the capsized Oriental Star cruise ship, in Jianli County, Hubei Province, in June. All but a dozen of the hundreds on board died in the disaster.
display_asset.credit: China Network, via Reuters

summaries.body: The Chinese government is blaming violent weather for the deadly Yangtze cruise ship disaster, but it also said the ship's captain and other officials contributed to the tragedy.

posts.footer: Peter Gelb, the Metropolitan Opera's general manager, on the possibility of performances on Sundays. The New York Times

display_asset.caption: The Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center.
display_asset.credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

summaries.body: I am hopeful and optimistic that we will find a way of implementing them, perhaps the season after next.

display_asset.caption: Stein Eriksen in 2004. He won gold and silver medals in the Olympics and the world championships in the 1950s.
display_asset.credit: Eric Schramm/Deer Valley Resort, via Associated Press

summaries.body: Stein Eriksen, an Olympic ski champion who was one of the sport’s first superstars, has died at 88.

display_asset.credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times

summaries.body: Syria was the deadliest country for journalists in 2015, the Committee to Protect Journalists said, followed by France, where eight were killed in the Charlie Hebdo attack.

display_asset.credit: Cranial reconstruction by Elizabeth Black - the woman's genes tell us she had black hair and brown eyes. Photo: Barrie Hartwell

summaries.body: The Irish can trace their roots to the Middle East and modern-day Ukraine, according to new research.
Kim Yang-gon, 73, a key aide to the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un who was involved in talks with the South, has died in a car accident, the state news media reported.

display_asset.credit: Sandra Auger/Reuters

summaries.body: A 2,000-year-old arch from Syria’s ancient city of Palmyra will be recreated in London using a 3-D printer. It was destroyed by Islamic State militants this year.

posts.footer: — William J. Bratton, the New York police commissioner, on hoverboards. Some state officials are pushing to legalize the devices. The New York Times

display_asset.caption: Doaine Thompson, 32, demonstrating the device.
display_asset.credit: Bryan R. Smith for The New York Times

summaries.body: To be quite frank with you, I think anybody who rides these things is out of their minds.

display_asset.credit: Joon Mo Kang

summaries.body: Authors with new books planned for 2016 include Don DeLillo, Anne Tyler and Jonathan Safran Foer.

display_asset.credit: Reuters

summaries.body: On Christmas Eve, an elusive giant squid, known as an Architeuthis (pronounced ark-uh-TOOTH-us), was spotted gliding near the water’s surface in Japan’s Toyama Bay.

display_asset.credit: The New York Times, Michael Ochs Archives

summaries.body: Discogs.com, a Wikipedia-like album database, has an online marketplace through which nearly ​$100 million in records​ were sold this year.

display_asset.caption: Top row, left to right, Yaser Abdel Said; Eduardo Ravelo; William Bradford Bishop, Jr.; Glen Stewart Godwin. Bottom row, left to right, Raymond Abbott-Baerga; David Benjamin Creamer; Corey Deshawn Gaston; Daniel William Hiers, Jr.

summaries.body: Though the case of Ethan Couch has captured widespread attention, many fugitives from decades ago have eluded capture but faded from the headlines.

display_asset.caption: David Lowery, the leader of the bands Cracker and Camper Van Beethoven, is an advocate for musicians’ rights.
display_asset.credit: Rebecca D'Angelo for The New York Times

summaries.body: Spotify is being sued for copyright infringement by David Lowery, a rock guitarist and songwriter, who accuses it of failing to properly license songwriting rights in the U.S.

display_asset.caption: Firewater Walk With Me, a baijiu cocktail at Mission Chinese Food.
display_asset.credit: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times

summaries.body: Baijiu, the national drink of China and the world's most widely consumed spirit, has not been popular in the U.S., but there's a push in some cities to change that.

display_asset.caption: Benoît Delépine, a film director, in front of his future resting spot at the Montmartre cemetery in Paris. The cactus tomb was created by a small band of drinking buddies and artists that includes Mr. Delépine, 57, and a former Charlie Hebdo political cartoonist.
display_asset.credit: Capucine Granier-Deferre for The New York Times

summaries.body: A group of friends and artists in Paris who aimed to build an irreverent mausoleum for themselves adorned their tomb with a cactus designed to look like a raised finger.

display_asset.caption: When the character Sheldon, played by Jim Parsons, gets sick, Penny, played by Kaley Cuoco, helps comfort him.
display_asset.credit: Monty Brinton/CBS

summaries.body: A New Hampshire poet's daughters are accusing the television comedy "The Big Bang Theory" of stealing their mother’s verses for the "Soft Kitty" lullaby.

display_asset.caption: Rams quarterback Case Keenum lay on the ground after sustaining a concussion against the Ravens in November.
display_asset.credit: Patrick Smith/Getty Images

summaries.body: A new report calls attention to the link between head injuries and poorly maintained fields, especially the growing number of those made of synthetic turf.
A Brooklyn man was arrested on murder charges on Monday in the slashing of a Queens woman whose body was found in a park in October.

display_asset.credit: Javier Mendoza/Southern California Gas Company, via AP

summaries.body: A methane well in Aliso Canyon, Calif., is spilling an estimated tens of thousands of pounds of gas into the air each hour as engineers struggle to plug the leak.
